title: Funerary screen
text: As middlemen of the Atlantic trade from the 1500s onwards, the Kalabari were in close contact with Europeans and their two-dimensional images. It seems likely that prints and paintings inspired the tradition of funerary screens, which began around 1800. Reserved for the heads of powerful trading houses, they offered the spirits of the dead a place to regularly return, receive offerings, and follow the business. The large, central figure of the deceased is flanked by two attendants.
description:
Ekine Society Memorial Screen (called \'Duen Fobar\'); wood and raffia with traces of pigment Nigeria,Ijo Tribe,late XIXc.
Abonnema Village
creditline: The John R. Van Derlip Fund
